Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Spinal Analgesia–Epidural Analgesia and Combined Spinal–Epidural Analgesia in Reducing Neurological Complications During Labor Analgesia

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the SA-EA group or the CSEA group.

Intervention.evidence: In the SA-EA group, a standard spinal needle was used for dural puncture, followed by intrathecal injection of 2mL of 0.1% ropivacaine + 1µg/mL sufentanil. An epidural catheter was then inserted. In the CSEA group, an epidural needle was used for puncture, followed by a spinal needle for dural puncture and the same intrathecal injection. An epidural catheter was inserted thereafter.

Objective.evidence: This trial compares spinal analgesia–epidural analgesia (SA-EA) and combined spinal–epidural analgesia (CSEA) in reducing these complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of neurological complications within [Timeframe].

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using [Randomisation Method] with allocation concealment via [Concealment Method].

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of [Sample Size] participants were recruited between [Recruitment Period].

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in [Frequency and Severity by Group].
